title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as Laci and Conner's Law, amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children," which aims to protect unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as Laci and Conner's Law, establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment for this offense is the same as if the injury or death had occurred to the mother. Proof of knowledge of the pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child is not required. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. If the person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, they will be punished as if they had intentionally killed a human being under specific sections of the law. The death penalty cannot be imposed for an offense under this section. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 creates a new offense for harming an unborn child. If someone intentionally kills or tries to kill the unborn child, they will face punishment as if they had killed a human being under certain sections of the law. The death penalty is not allowed for offenses under this section. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for harming an unborn child under specific sections of the law, without allowing the death penalty. It clarifies that prosecution is not permitted for conduct related to abortion with proper consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or for any woman with respect to her unborn child. The Act defines an 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 prohibits prosecution for harming an unborn child under specific circumstances, such as abortion with proper consent or medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child. The Act defines an 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. SEC. 3. MILITARY JUSTICE SYSTEM. Amends the Uniform Code of Military Justice to include protection for unborn children in cases of death or injury. Any person subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice who causes the death or bodily injury to an unborn child during the commission of a listed offense will be guilty of a separate offense. Proof of knowledge of the victim's pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child is not required for conviction. Any person subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice who causes injury or death to an unborn child's mother will be guilty of a separate offense. Knowledge of the victim's pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child is not required for conviction. If the person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, they will be punished accordingly. The death penalty cannot be imposed for this offense. Sections 880, 918, and 919(a) of the Uniform Code of Military Justice address intentional killing or attempting to kill a human being. The death penalty is not allowed for these offenses. Prosecution is not permitted for conduct related to abortion with proper consent, medical treatment of a pregnant woman or her unborn child, or for a woman regarding her unborn child. The Uniform Code of Military Justice prohibits prosecution for conduct related to abortion with proper consent, medical treatment of a pregnant woman or her unborn child, or for a woman regarding her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' refers to a child in utero, a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
